Subject: The fund is a closed-end private equity fund established in Singapore as a limited partnership and will invest through Ascent Myanmar Growth Fund Private Limited, a private limited company incorporated in Singapore (collectively, AMGF). The fund will invest primarily equity capital for growth purposes in middle-market companies, including small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), operating in Myanmar.
Title: Ascent Myanmar Growth Fund I L.P.: Report and Recommendation of the President

 I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed equity 

 
1. 
investment of up to $10,000,000 in Ascent Myanmar Growth Fund I L.P. in Myanmar.  
 
2. 
The  fund  is  a  closed-end  private  equity  fund  established  in  Singapore  as  a  limited 
partnership  and  will  invest  through  Ascent  Myanmar  Growth  Fund  Private  Limited,  a  private 
limited  company  incorporated  in  Singapore  (collectively,  AMGF).  The  fund  will  invest  primarily 
equity capital for growth purposes in middle-market companies, including small and medium-sized 
enterprises  (SMEs),  operating  in  Myanmar. 1  Focus  sectors  include  consumer,  education, 
financial  services,  health  care,  and  technology,  media  and  telecommunications.  Investing  in 
AMGF will allow the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to contribute to Myanmar’s economic growth 
while providing development benefits, including supporting female entrepreneurs. The proposed 
investment will help deepen capital markets in Myanmar by providing scarce growth equity capital 
to  Myanmar’s  middle-market  companies,  including  SMEs.  Moreover,  ADB’s  investment  is 
expected to catalyze private sector investment into Myanmar and encourage international best 
practices of investment.  
 

II. 

THE FUND 

Investment Identification and Description 

 
A. 
 
3. 
Description.  Ascent  Capital  Partners  Pte.  Ltd.  is  a  newly  established  Singapore-
registered private equity fund manager that aims to invest in middle-market companies, including 
SMEs, in Myanmar. The firm was founded and is indirectly owned by its two managing partners, 
Chong Chong Lim and Tee Keong Pneh. [This information has been removed as it falls under the 
exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information  Policy,  para.  17.2.(v)].  Ascent  Capital 
plans to build a team of up to 16 staff, with 13 investment team professionals (including the two 
managing partners and a dedicated portfolio management team of three operating professionals), 
and three supporting finance and administrative staff.  
 
4. 
Ascent  Capital  is  raising  its  first  private  equity  fund  with  a  target  capitalization  of  $100 
million. Ascent General Partner Private Limited will be incorporated to act as its general partner. 
The general partner will engage Ascent Capital as its investment manager, which will (i) identify, 
evaluate,  and  structure  potential  investments  for  AMGF;  (ii)  participate  in  the  management  of 
portfolio companies; and (iii) provide administrative functions.2 

 

5. 
[This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].3 The collective experience of the anchor investors 
and the two founders in executing and managing investments and navigating the complex legal 
and political landscape in Myanmar, is essential to Ascent Capital’s success. [This information 
has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information 
Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].4 
 

 

1  Middle market companies and SMEs are defined as companies with typical enterprise value of $2 million–$50 million. 
2  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

3  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

4  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)] 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)] 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)] 

 Investment identification. ADB has been tracking several private equity fund managers 
6. 
in frontier countries in South and Southeast Asia, including Bangladesh, Cambodia, Myanmar, 
Pakistan,  Sri  Lanka,  and  Mongolia.  Myanmar  has  shown  consistent  growth  in  gross  domestic 
product  over  the  past  since  2008  and  is  increasingly  being  scoped  by  private  equity  investors 
because of its improving investment landscape. According to the World Bank, Myanmar’s gross 
domestic  product  grew  at  an  average  of  7.9%  during  2008–2017.5 Despite  this  achievement, 
Myanmar remains one of the poorest countries in Southeast Asia with 32.1% of the population 
living below the national poverty line.6 Rapid growth is expected to continue because of four key 
advantages: (i) ample investment opportunities in essential services and infrastructure because 
of the country’s political and economic isolation during 1990-2011; (ii) strategic location between 
the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and India,  with  access to  40%  of the  world’s  population;  (iii)  a 
large population of 54 million that offers a young workforce and a strong market base for domestic 
consumption; and (iv) abundant natural resources. Since the country’s liberalization in 2011, the 
Government of Myanmar has increased efforts to improve the investment environment for foreign 
investors to enable them to leverage Myanmar’s advantages to drive economic growth.  
 
The growth rates in Myanmar is comparable to that in several frontier markets, and ADB 
7. 
has been seeking a high-quality fund management team with strong investment and operational 
experience, backed by credible anchor investors. Ascent Capital meets ADB’s investment criteria. 
The general partner’s management team is led by Chong Chong Lim, an experienced corporate 
and  investment  professional  with  prior  working  experience  at  Temasek  International;  and  Tee 
Keong Pneh, an experienced private equity investment professional with prior working experience 
at  Maybank  Private  Equity  and  Navis  Capital  Partners. 7 Chong  Chong  Lim  was  group  chief 
finance officer at the Capital Diamond Star Group, a leading business conglomerate in Myanmar 
with diversified businesses in agriculture, food, retail, real estate, healthcare, financial services 
and automotive goods. Tee Keong Pneh was chief executive officer of Maybank Private Equity, 
the private equity arm of Malayan Banking Berhad, where he managed legacy funds, developed 
new fund management strategy, designed new investment process, led merger and acquisition 
transactions and communicated with key Maybank stakeholders.  
 
8. 
 [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 
Access  to  Information  Policy,  para.  17.2.(v)].  Although  Ascent  Capital  is  a  newly  established 
platform with no track record of investing in Myanmar, ADB’s due diligence has confirmed that 
the two managing partners and two anchor investors have individual management and investment 
experience,  extensive  business  relationships,  and  relevant  knowledge  of  the  local  market  and 
regulatory environment to ensure the platform is a success.  
 
B. 
 
9. 
AMGF intends to make 10–15 investments of $5 million–$10 million each in fast-growing 
middle  market  companies,  including  SMEs,  in  the  consumer,  education,  financial  services, 
health–care, and technology, multimedia, and telecommunications sectors. These will likely be 
family-owned companies requiring expansionary capital, including companies facing succession 
challenges or undergoing transformation because of competitive pressures as Myanmar’s market 
continues to liberalize. AMGF will seek joint ventures and/or strategic partnerships where possible 
to enable its smooth entry into the market and share the investment risk with local partners. The 

Business Overview and Strategy 

 

5  World Bank. DataBank: World Development Indicators. GDP Growth (Annual %) (accessed 13 September 2018). 
6  ADB. ADB Data Library. Myanmar: By the Numbers (accessed 8 October 2018). 
7   Maybank Private Equity is an affiliate of Malayan Banking Berhad (“Maybank”), the largest banking group in Malaysia; 
Navis Capital Partners is a regional buyout fund with investments in Southeast Asia and the People’s Republic of 
China.  

2 

 

 3 
 

Ownership, Management, and Governance 

fund  may  seek  co-investors  to  mobilize  additional  capital  from  institutional  investors  for  larger 
transactions.  AMGF  will  also  identify  companies  owned  and  operated  by  women  and  young 
entrepreneurs and help improve their business processes and operational efficiency. AMGF will 
seek significant minority or majority stakes to ensure active post-investment operational roles in 
investee  companies.  AMGF’s  holding  period  is  expected  to  be  5–7  years;  its  anticipated  exit 
strategies including trade sales to local and/or foreign strategic buyers, secondary sales to other 
private equity funds and financial buyers, and initial public offerings. 
 
C. 
 
10.  Ownership. AMGF is structured as a Singapore limited partnership that will invest all or 
substantially all of its assets in a Singapore-incorporated private limited company, which will be 
the master fund. [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure 
in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
Integrity  due  diligence  and  enhanced  tax  integrity  due  diligence  were  conducted. 8 No 
11. 
significant or potentially significant integrity risks were identified. After reviewing the transaction, 
ADB does not believe that it has been established or is being used for money laundering, terrorism 
financing, or cross-border tax evasion. 
 
12.  Management. Ascent Capital is led by its two managing partners, Chong Chong Lim and 
Tee Keong Pneh. As of 30 September 2018, the two managing partners have assembled a team 
of  seven  supporting  investment  professionals  and  are  recruiting  a  dedicated  portfolio 
management team of up to three operating professionals. The full team of up to 16 staff will be 
based in Yangon and is expected to be in place before 30 June 2019, by the fund’s final closing. 
The portfolio management team is expected to be led by a full-time operating partner that has 
already been identified by Ascent Capital and will be formally recruited by June 2019. Employee 
recruitments are expected to be in accordance with its gender policy to ensure equal employment 
opportunities and non-discrimination in the workplace.  
 
13. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)].  
 
14.  Where  possible,  Ascent  Capital  will  seek  representation  on  the  boards  of  its  investee 
companies to provide strategic and operational guidance. 

 [This information has been removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s 

15.  Governance structure. Ascent Capital’s investment process is structured in four phases 
and includes three investment committee meetings: 
 

Deal  sourcing  and  initial  screening.  The  investment  team  will  carry  out  initial 
screening once an investment opportunity is identified. The investment team will 
draft a deal alert for the first investment committee meeting. 

 

(i) 

(ii) 

Evaluation  and  strategic  due-diligence.  The  investment  team  will  review  the 
industry, company, valuation, and value proposition and will draft an investment

Relation  to  Tax  Integrity.  Manila.  Further  information,  including  integrity  disclosure,  is  provided  in  Ownership, 
Management, and Governance (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 

 committee paper for the second investment committee meeting after this phase. A 
non-binding offer will be issued if the investment committee agrees to proceed. 

(iii) 

Financial and legal due-diligence. The investment team will engage third-party 
legal and financial advisors for legal and financial due diligence, and will draft and 
present a due diligence report to the third investment committee meeting after this 
phase.  A  binding  offer  will  be  issued  if  the  investment  committee  agrees  to 
proceed. 

(iv) 

Documentation  and  closing.  The  investment  team  will  negotiate  and  execute 
documentation and close the investment. 

 
Ascent Capital’s portfolio management team is expected to work closely with the fund’s 
16. 
investment team and the management team of each investee company to drive post-investment 
value creation initiatives.  
 
In addition to the investment committee, AMGF will have an advisory committee with up 
17. 
to  five  members,  including  one  representative  from  each  anchor  investor  and  representatives 
from  limited  partners  with  capital  commitments  of  at  least  $20  million.  Notwithstanding  ADB’s 
proposed investment size, Ascent Capital has agreed to grant ADB a seat on the fund’s advisory 
committee.  The  advisory  committee  will  primarily  resolve conflicts  of  interest  and  will  act  in  an 
advisory role to the general partner on matters related to the oversight of AMGF activities. The 
advisory committee may also offer strategic advice, particularly on policy changes and interaction 
with regulators, local business dynamics, and general reputational and political issues. 
 
D. 
 
18. 
there is no historical financial performance to report. 
 

Ascent Capital is a newly established private equity platform raising its first fund, hence 

Financial Performance 

III. 

THE PROPOSED ADB ASSISTANCE 

The Assistance 

Financial Analysis of Expected Returns and Assumptions 

 
A. 
 
19. 
ADB will provide an equity investment of up to $10,000,000 in Ascent Myanmar Growth 
Fund I L.P. ADB’s proposed investment will not exceed 25% of the fund’s total committed capital 
and will not result in ADB being the single largest investor in the fund. 
 
B. 
 
Ascent Capital has indicated that it aims to achieve a gross internal rate of return of 20% 
20. 
in United States dollar terms for the fund. Consistent with market practice and subject to certain 
limitations, the general partner can recall for the purpose of reinvestment the capital portion of 
divestment  proceeds  previously  distributed  to  limited  partners.  In  such  a  scenario,  ADB’s  total 
capital commitment to the fund would remain unchanged. 
 
C. 
 
21. 
Exit strategy. The fund has a 12-year term, subject to two 1-year extensions upon the 
majority  approval  of  the  investors.  The  anticipated  exit  strategies  for  AMGF’s  investments  are 

Implementation Arrangements 

4 

 

 

 

 5 
 

Value Added by ADB Assistance 

trade sale to foreign and local strategic buyers and secondary sales to regional financial investors. 
AMGF will also selectively consider initial public offerings as an option.  
 
22. 
Reporting  arrangements.  Ascent  Capital  will  provide  ADB  with  quarterly  reports  and 
audited annual financial statements, an annual valuation report, an overview of the portfolio with 
brief  information  on  each  portfolio  company’s  financial  performance  and  valuation,  an  annual 
development effectiveness monitoring report, and an annual environmental and social monitoring 
report  that  includes  performance  against  gender  mainstreaming  targets.  ADB  will  review  this 
information to ensure that Ascent Capital provides the required information and clarification. If the 
information received raises issues that could impair the value of ADB’s investment in the fund, 
ADB could decide to put the fund on a watch list for more frequent review and closer attention. 
 
D. 
 
23. 
Private  sector  development.  ADB’s  investment  in  AMGF  is  expected  to  encourage 
international  investment  and  introduction  of  governance  best  practices  in  the  fund’s  investee 
companies, which could potentially help scale-up small and/or medium sized local businesses. 
The investment may also help catalyze private sector investment in Myanmar by demonstrating 
the viability of private equity as a financing option in the country where equity capital availability 
is scarce and banks are undercapitalized, which limits their ability to lend to companies that are 
able to pledge collateral.  
 
24. 
Setting standards. As the first development financial institution investor in AMGF, ADB 
will  obligate  Ascent  Capital  to  report  on  gender  and  development  indicators  and  adopt  an 
environmental and social management system (ESMS) acceptable to ADB. Ascent Capital will 
require  portfolio  companies  to  operate  in  accordance  with  its  ESMS.  Because  of  ADB’s 
interventions  during  the  fund’s  formation,  the  proposed  AMGF  investments  will  be  screened 
against a gender equity scorecard, national environmental and social laws, and ADB’s safeguard 
requirements.  In  addition,  ADB  will  provide  oversight  on  environmental  and  social  matters, 
including gender and labor, as required during investment appraisal. 
 
25. 
Long  term  funding.  The  fund’s  ability  to  provide  long-term,  patient  equity  capital  will 
benefit  companies  that  struggle  to  scale  up  because  of  unavailability  of  long-term  expansion 
capital.  This  will  help  develop  Myanmar’s  economy  and  capital  markets,  which  are  still  at  a 
nascent stage of development. 
 
E.

IV. 

DEVELOPMENT IMPACT AND STRATEGIC ALIGNMENT 

is 

investments 

in  Myanmar 

Development Impact, Outcome, and Outputs  

 
A. 
 
33. 
Impact. The project is aligned with the 12-point Economic Policy of the Union of Myanmar, 
which promotes inclusive economic growth, a competitive, vibrant, and market-oriented private 
sector and a financial system that can sustainably provide capital to businesses and SMEs.  
 
34.  Outcome.  Financial  sustainability  of  private  equity 
demonstrated. 
 
35.  Outputs. AMGF is established and investments in 10–15 companies are completed, and 
a gender inclusive policy is adopted. 
 
B. 
 
36. 
Consistency with ADB strategy. The proposed investment in AMGF aligns strongly with 
the operational priorities outlined in ADB’s Strategy 2030.12 These include (i) addressing poverty 
and  reducing  inequalities  by  generating  quality  jobs  to  support  inclusive  growth  for  all  and  (ii) 
fostering  regional  cooperation  and  integration  by  enhancing  connectivity  and  strengthening 
cooperation  in  the  financial  sector.  Strategy  2030  also  supports  expanding  private  sector 
operations, including expanding regional reach through private equity funds, supporting greater 
financial inclusion, strengthening the finance sector in capital markets, and widening geographical 
coverage. 
 
37. 
Consistency with country strategy. The proposed investment is consistent with ADB’s 
country partnership strategy for Myanmar, 2017-2021, which focuses on: (i) improving Myanmar’s 
access  and  connectivity  to  regional  and  global  markets;  and  (ii)  promoting  structural  and 
institutional  reform  to  support  the  modernization  of  Myanmar’s  economy. 13  ADB’s  country 

Alignment with ADB Strategy and Operations 

 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)] 

Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]  

10  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

11  [This information  has  been  removed  as  it  falls  under  the  exception  to  disclosure  in  ADB’s  Access  to  Information 

12 ADB.  2018.  Strategy  2030:  Achieving  a  Prosperous,  Inclusive,  Resilient,  and  Sustainable  Asia  and  the  Pacific. 

13 ADB. 2017. Country Partnership Strategy: Myanmar, 2017-2021 – Building the Foundations for Inclusive Growth. 

Manila. 

Manila 

 

 7 
 

partnership  strategy  also  emphasizes  developing  Myanmar’s  private  sector  by  (i)  improving 
infrastructure and connectivity and (ii) strengthening the country’s financial sector. 
 
38. 
Consistency  with  sector  strategy  and  relevant  ADB  operations.  The  proposed 
investment  is  consistent  with  the  ADB  plan  for  financial  sector  operations,  which  prioritizes  (i) 
inclusive finance for households and SMEs and (ii) regional monetary and financial cooperation 
and integration.14 The plan addresses ADB’s focus on supporting enhanced access to finance, 
including through private equity funds, for SMEs. 
 
39. 
Lessons  from  previous  operations.  While  this  will  be  ADB’s  first  investment  in  a 
Myanmar-focused  private  equity  fund,  lessons  learned  from  previous  fund  investments  were 
considered and incorporated into the proposed transaction. A Special Evaluation Study on Private 
Equity Fund (PEF) Operations published in July 2008 concluded that ADB’s screening process 
lacked strategic focus since investments were identified primarily through sponsors approaching 
ADB. The proposed transaction was identified through a bottom-up market mapping exercise of 
carefully assessing the fund manager and confirming the relevant investment and/or operating 
experiences of the partners in Myanmar. The fund’s strategic focus on sectors and developmental 
indicators  were  also  confirmed  to  be  in  line  with  ADB’s  mandate.  [This  information  has  been 
removed as it falls under the exception to disclosure in ADB’s Access to Information Policy, para. 
17.2.(v)].  
 

V. 

POLICY COMPLIANCE 

Safeguards and Social Dimensions 

ADB  has  categorized  the  investment  to  be  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 

 
A. 
 
40. 
Statement (2009).15 
 
Category  FI.  ADB  has  assessed  the  investment's  potential  environment  and  social 
41. 
impacts, its risks associated with AMGF’s likely future portfolio and its commitment and capacity 
for  environmental  and  social  management.  As  a  first-time  fund  manager  in  Myanmar,  Ascent 
Capital had no ESMS before ADB’s proposed investment. During due diligence, ADB provided 
guidance to Ascent Capital in developing its Myanmar-focused ESMS and conducted training to 
strengthen  the  managing  partners’  understanding  of  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement 
requirements.  AMGF’s  likely  portfolio  is  not  expected  to  (i)  require  major  infrastructure 
development  or  generate  significant,  adverse,  irreversible  or  diverse  environmental  and  social 
impacts or risks; and (ii) require involuntary resettlement or adversely or beneficially affect distinct 
and vulnerable ethnic minority communities. The ESMS will exclude the fund from investing in 
any  potential  investment  that  may  be  classified  category  A  for  the  environment,  involuntary 
resettlement  and  indigenous  peoples  following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement.  Ascent 
Capital will (i) apply ADB's prohibited investment activities list, (ii) ensure that investments using 
ADB funds comply with ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement and abide by applicable national laws 
and regulations, and (iii) establish and maintain an appropriate ESMS satisfactory to ADB before 
disbursement.16 The ESMS will set out requirements, as applicable, for compliance with national 
labor laws and measures to comply with internationally recognized core labor standards, pursuant 
to ADB’s Social Protection Strategy. The ESMS will also contain requirements, as applicable, for 

 

14 ADB. 2011. Financial Sector Operational Plan. Manila. 
15 ADB. Safeguard Categories. 
16 Summary  Poverty  Reduction  and  Social  Strategy;  and  Environmental  and  Social  Management  System:  Audit 

Findings and Details of Arrangement (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 

 Anticorruption Policy 

information disclosure and consultation with affected people following ADB requirements. Ascent 
Capital will include in its regular reporting information to ADB (i) the nature of subprojects and 
categorization,  (ii) compliance  with  ADB’s  environmental  and  social  safeguards  requirements, 
and (iii) compliance with applicable national laws and regulations and good international industry 
practices. 
 
42. 
Effective gender mainstreaming. Following ADB’s Policy on Gender and Development 
(1998), Ascent Capital has incorporated measures to promote gender equality and/or women’s 
empowerment in its business activities. Key features of the gender action plan are as follows: (i) 
Ascent Capital will design and implement an overarching gender policy to guide and manage its 
efforts in achieving gender equality in its investees’ businesses. (ii) Ascent Capital will screen its 
potential investees using a gender equality scorecard to assess their status and responsiveness 
to  women’s  empowerment  in  the  workplace.  (iii)  Ascent  Capital  will  establish  and  maintain  a 
gender mainstreaming outreach program to enhance the skills and capacity of business women 
within  its  portfolio  companies  and  the  broader  community.  Ascent  Capital  will  submit  periodic 
reports on implementation of gender measures to ADB. 
 
B. 
 
43. 
Ascent Capital was advised of ADB’s policy of implementing best international practices 
relating  to  combating  corruption,  money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism.  ADB  will 
ensure that the investment documentation includes appropriate provisions prohibiting corruption, 
money  laundering,  and  the  financing  of  terrorism;  and  remedies  for  ADB  in  the  event  of 
noncompliance. 
 
C. 
 
44. 
Access to Information Policy, para. 17.2.(v)]. 
 
D. 
 
Consistent with the Agreement Establishing the Asian Development Bank (the Charter),17 
45. 
ADB will proceed with the assistance upon establishing that the Government of Myanmar has no 
objection to the assistance to the fund. ADB will enter into suitable finance documentation in form 
and substance satisfactory to ADB.

VI. 

RECOMMENDATION 

 
46. 
I  am  satisfied  that  the  proposed  equity  investment  would  comply  with  the  Articles  of 
Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board approve the 
equity investment of up to $10,000,000 from ADB’s ordinary capital resources in Ascent Myanmar 
Growth Fund I L.P. in Myanmar, with such terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with those set forth in this report, and as may be reported to the Board 
 
 

Takehiko Nakao 
President

The project is aligned with the 12-point Economic Policy of the Union of Myanmar, which promotes inclusive 
economic growth, a competitive, vibrant, and market-oriented private sector and a financial system that can 
sustainably provide capital to businesses and SMEs.a

Key Activities with Milestones 

Output 1: AMGF established  

1.1  Execute legal documentation with ADB by Q1 2019. 

1.2 Establish an independent advisory committee (with ADB representation) by Q4 2019. 

1.3 Achieve financial closing in Q4 2019. 

1.4 Complete first two investments completed by calendar year 2020. 

Output 2: Gender inclusive policy adopted 

2.1  Establish a gender policy, a gender equality scorecard system, and a business outreach program for 

female entrepreneurs in 2019.
